awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Inorganic-organic hybrid microreactors for fundamental study of cellulose hydrolysis by solid acids
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract - Timko, 1554283

Lignocellulosic biomass, the world's most abundant source of renewable carbon, has promise as a carbon neutral energy source that can reduce the need for petroleum-based transportation fuels, chemicals, and materials. Despite progress and promise in the development of many different biofuel technologies, none have proven economically viable. The aim of this project is to make production of fuels and chemicals from biomass resources economically viable. The poor economics of biomass conversion to fuels and chemicals is due largely to biomass resistance to chemical and biological attack. Three primary platforms have been suggested for overcoming biomass recalcitrance: bio-oil (produced via pyrolysis or liquefaction), synthesis gas (produced by gasification), and sugars (produced by pretreatment and enzyme hydrolysis). This proposal is focused on the sugars platform. Biomass resistance to chemical and biological attack makes recovery of monosaccharides expensive and energy intensive. The focus of this work is on recovery of monosaccharides from biomass because this step represents the key technological bottleneck of the sugars platform.

The overarching research objective is to understand the fundamental mechanisms underlying cellulose deconstruction by solid acid catalysts. The approach consists of constructing polymer-brush modified inorganic particles (silica and zeolites) as catalytic microreactors with: 1) well defined external acidity that can be accessed by insoluble substrates, 2) cellulose targeting/binding/solubilization capability to provide interactions between insoluble substrates and external surfaces of solid acids, and 3) internal pore structure and acidity that can be accessed by small molecule soluble substrates. Specific questions to be addressed include: 1) what is the structure/property- function relationship that governs the catalyst-biomass interaction? 2) what is the relationship between solid acid strength and cellulose hydrolysis activity? and 3) what is the balance between external acidity for cellulose chain breaking and internal acidity for hydrolysis of soluble fragments? The project will evaluate the hypothesis that solid acid catalysis is mediated by binding interactions and strong acidity. In the research component of this work, the underlying mechanism will be examined to: 1) understand the role of catalyst-cellulose binding and the relationship between cellulose adhesion, catalyst surface composition, and catalyst surface energy; 2) quantify the role of acidity and answer the question of how acidic the surface needs to be to catalyze hydrolysis; 3) differentiate between external acidic sites required to convert insoluble substrates and internal acidic sites capable of converting soluble carbohydrates.

The research objectives will be integrated with educational and outreach aims to use data-to-music tools to attract students from under-represented backgrounds to careers in STEM fields and to appeal to a broader range of learning styles at the undergraduate level than are typical in the engineering curriculum. In terms of education, the use of music to teach difficult concepts to college engineering students could improve training for students that use learning styles that are not typical in engineering curricula. This has potential to improve retention of a broader range of undergraduate students in STEM fields. The outreach component will provide K-12 students with an engaging STEM experience that empowers rather than alienates. Specifically, research data will be converted into sounds and re-modulated into music, a process that mimics the practice of sampling that drives hip hop music composition.

por.por_cntn:
Summary. Biomass is a nearly limitless source of renewable carbon, which can take the form of energy crops and different types of waste. Converting biomass into small molecules is the key step for production of renewable fuels and chemicals. This study addressed this bottleneck in three ways: 1) advancing fundamental understanding of biomass deconstruction using cellulose as a model compound, 2) improved catalytic and reaction technologies for deconstructing biomass using cellulose as a model compound, 3) development of efficient new conversion technologies on bamboo, a fast growing plant that has potential for rural economic development. The results obtained greatly improve our understanding of biomass deconstruction, provide new technologies for biomass deconstruction, and demonstrate the feasability for converting bamboo into simple sugars.

Intellectual Merit. Each of the three main elements of this study provide intellectual merit. In the area of fundamental understanding of biomass deconstruction, this study solved an 80-year-old scientific mystery. Since the 1940s, scientists have known that grinding biomass to decrystallize its cellulose component greatly increases its reactivity. However, even completely decrystallized cellulose cannot easily be convert entirely into small molecules under mild conditions. This study showed that decrystallized cellulose spontaneously recrystallizes when exposed to conditions used for deconstruction. As a result, the recyrstallized cellulose becomes less reactive than the decrystallized version, solving the persistent mystery and providing insight into efficient ways to deconstruct cellulose. In terms of improved catalytic and reaction technologies for cellulose deconstruction, this study advanced current understanding of a promising class of catalysts used for cellulose conversion into small molecules, providing science-based guidlines for selecting stable and active catalysts. Further, this study found that addition of low-cost reaction promoters can greatly increase the efficiency of cellulose deconstruction using both acid and enzyme catalysts. In the most astonishing result, a small amount of salt added to the reaction mixture boosted cellulose deconstruction from less than 10% to nearly 100%. Promoters that interfere with cellulose recrystallization and balance its surface charge are the most effective. In terms of bamboo, this study found that an energy efficient two-step process consisting of lignin removal and decrystallization can convert a common fast growing bamboo into small molecule building blocks with nearly 100% yield. The key insight is the order of the two-step process, as the ordering the decrystallization step before the delignification step is much less effective than the reverse ordering. This insight follows directly from studies of the effect of crystallinity on cellulose reactivity.

Broader Impacts. The project trained two PhD students, both of whom are in positions in the US R&D sector. It provided training for many undergraduate students, some of whom went on to pursue PhD degrees at other universities. Efficient biomass use can supply up to 20% of current fuel use; expanding the resource by bamboo cultivation has even greater benefits. A case study of Nigeria indicated that marginal lands in this country could provide enough ethanol to meet 100% of current demands. Similarly, use of bamboo greatly reduces fuel production costs. A patent application has been submitted and the research team is discussing a licensing agreement with a startup company focused on bamboo utilization. Lastly, the study produced a learning tool to help neurodvergent learners become comfortable with STEM fields using music.
